title: 110_hr592
content: The "Campus Fire Safety Right-to-Know Act of 2007" requires disclosure of fire safety information for campus buildings. Section 485 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include the requirement for eligible institutions to disclose annual fire safety reports as part of the Campus Fire Safety Right-to-Know Act of 2007. The Campus Fire Safety Right-to-Know Act of 2007 mandates eligible institutions to annually prepare, publish, and distribute fire safety reports to students, employees, and applicants, detailing campus fire safety practices and standards, including information on fire sprinkler systems and other safety measures in student housing facilities. The Campus Fire Safety Right-to-Know Act of 2007 requires eligible institutions to provide statistics on fires and false alarms in student housing facilities, including details on injuries, damages, and rules regarding portable electrical appliances and open flames. The Campus Fire Safety Right-to-Know Act of 2007 mandates eligible institutions to report fire statistics in student housing, including injuries, damages, rules on portable electrical appliances, open flames, fire drills, safety education, and training for students, faculty, and staff. Fraternities, sororities, and student groups must also submit reports as a condition of recognition. The Campus Fire Safety Right-to-Know Act of 2007 requires recognized fraternities, sororities, and student groups with student housing facilities to annually collect specific information about their buildings and properties. The Campus Fire Safety Right-to-Know Act of 2007 mandates recognized fraternities, sororities, and student groups with student housing to annually prepare and distribute fire safety reports and submit statistics to the Secretary. The annual fire safety reports for recognized fraternities, sororities, and student groups with student housing must include information on fire safety and collaboration with academic institutions. Each academic institution participating in fire safety programs must maintain a log of on-campus fires, false alarms, and provide annual reports to the campus community. The Secretary is responsible for reviewing and making public the statistics on fires and false alarms submitted by academic institutions. They also work with fire organizations and higher education representatives to identify and share exemplary fire safety policies and practices. The Secretary reviews and shares statistics on campus fires and false alarms submitted by academic institutions. They collaborate with fire organizations and higher education representatives to identify effective fire safety policies and practices. The subsection does not authorize the Secretary to mandate specific fire safety measures for institutions of higher education, except for collecting, reporting, and disseminating required information. The Secretary of Education is required to report to Congress. Within two years of this Act's enactment, the Secretary of Education must submit a report to Congress on the status of fire safety systems in college and university facilities, including sprinkler systems. The report will also include an analysis of appropriate fire safety standards, estimated costs of bringing nonconforming student housing up to code, and recommendations for meeting fire safety standards in all college facilities. The Secretary of Education must submit a report to Congress within two years of this Act's enactment on the status of fire safety systems in college and university facilities, including recommendations for funding the cost. Additionally, the report will highlight exemplary fire safety education and training programs at colleges and universities, with recommendations for wider adoption among institutions of higher education.
